title: Nearly  a decade Later - can we fix this now?
body:
League of Legends came out in 2009 -  it is almost 10 years later,  Riot is no longer a small company that is just doing what it can for its fans. In 2009  they sought to create a company that continuously improves on an already released game, instead of commencing development on a new one.  And they have delivered in champions, Items, (on both sides of enjoyment and WTF riot) however, I am here to talk about something that has been IN the game since 2009, gotten NO love, and is still as buggy and broken as it was nearly a decade ago..** Death Recap **-  I mean I cannot be the only player that when he dies and sees "Death Recap" in a game - checks it to see who is doing what type of damage so if i need to build mitigation against that type -  Be it Armor, Magic Resist, both.. 

However Either True dmg is being given away in the mail with free samples of Tide by Noxus, or Riot needs to actually sit down and fix this death recap - or remove it completely and when you die just the words  "Guess who killed you, we're not tellin"  can come up on the screen. 

Because too often , much too often for a 10 year old game, you see things like  - **_(These images were taken from Google - and not my own personal experience, however i have seen much the same in my own death recaps.) _**
http://apollo-na-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/1432542711/LeagueWhatKillSelf3.jpg

or Warwick really decides to go to pound town

http://apollo-pbe-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/1417483423314/Screen02.png

But its not just the champions as we all know.  the Creeps tend to get upset now and then too, and call out the Hero of the Hour  "Purple Melee Minon" 
http://apollo-na-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/1438823810/MinionDamage.jpg


Ok but seriously - no joke -  the death recap is meant to be useful information on how you died, so if you desire to adjust a build accordingly you can -  in its current stand the death recap is good for at best a laugh and at worst and string of curses.  Because if these death recaps are "correct"  someone needs to take a serious look at Warwirk and Rammus  (haha)  

Its time for you to actually give us a death recap - and not just a odd mix of numbers done to you in .09 seconds. 

Thank you for your time

replies.body: The issue is that this game is held together with twine and superglue and the death recap is so deeply embedded that fixing it would cause so many more issues then it's worth. Notice how they have that early league aesthetic because, even after multiple UI and map changes, Riot is too afraid of breaking the whole game to make it look nicer or actually work.

I dont think it would break anything. If they can work on reworking champions, and putting them into the game, they could just put a team of engineers to work on this.

Maybe if they stopped releasing a  nem champ every second month, and reworking one every third month, they could actually work on glitches and elements like this one.

with the "spaghetti code" as they called it, anything can happen

there have been numerous occasions where a patch changes something completely unrelated to a sudden new bug that happens on the live server

for instance, in whatever patch it was so long ago, suddenly every ability or attack launched from the brush was INVISIBLE

they banned players for using this exploit when they publicly announced it because they would have to shut down the game for extended periods of time in order to fix it

other instances include the store, game modes, champion bugs, etc, such as the xerath exploit which allowed xerath to damage everyone on the map at the same time

it's a whole web of crazy for no real reason

I mean It probably would break alot of shit, hell Mordekaiser alone has a bug list over 300 book pages, that's a whole books worth, and they've known about them for YEARS and I do mean YEARS every year the mordemains get together and make a bug mega thread last year with was around 220 bugs with release of new runes/masteries it jumped upto 290...
That has nothing to do with whether or not it'd cause a domino effect of broken code. That's not how it works. Death recap is from a time when the devs were just doing it as a hobby.

Yes it would probably break everything if they didn't have a dedicated team and months to work on it. HOWEVER. Stats are very important (we even got a new stats tab for that in-client) EVEN MORE SO in-combat. Knowing your enemy DURING the fight, damage distribution and effects. Afraid or not it NEEDS to be done.

Wtf are you talking?
The game looks nice and the old aesthetic is intentional.

Meddler talked about that recently. Here's the quote.

"We could skip skins for a year and it wouldn't help us work on death recap - the issue there's what expertise is needed for each job. Skins are mainly artist dependent. Death Recap by contrast primarily needs engineer time. That means the trade offs we'd need to make for Death Recap work are things like working on client bugs, FPS optimization, enabling new features for game modes etc. Completely with you that Death Recap isn't in a good state, our conclusion's been that other work like that's going to improve people's experiences more (on average, certainly not for every given person) though."

My 10 cent on Tencent:

>client bugs

They could have thought about that before even changing the client - the old one was for the most part stable.

>FPS optimization

Again, the majority of optimization issues have arisen post-client change. And top-end rigs are still ignored in this.

>enabling new features for game modes

I for one could be easily agreeing with NOT making stuff like Nexus Siege, Dark Star Singularity and Substructure 43 (PROJECT: Overcharge) if that meant getting a proper death recap.

9 women doesn't give birth to a baby in 1 month. Riot has stated several times that "just hiring more people" doesn't necessarily make things go faster.
First of all they'd have to find engineers that accepts the job, then they have to spend half/an entire year to teach them before they're ready to work for real. And during that time they have to pull engineers from other projects to teach them, meaning things would go even slower for potentially an entire year. More engineers might need more managers, so you gotta hire and teach those as well. And if you've ever worked for a bigger company you know they're really slow to do anything because changes have to go through a lot of people (too many chefs spoil the broth, if you will).
On top of all that, we don't know if it's even possible for them to expand, they could be out of office spaces in their current office.

But it's been _10 years_. Surely that's enough time to hire people and train them in? The solution to not having enough manpower is to get more manpower. That's really all there is to it. Yeah, training people takes manpower away from other stuff for a while, but not hiring more people will not magically fix the issue. This is what every business deals with, I don't know why game developers seem to get a pass on this from their fans.

Yeah, it's pretty absurd that it went this long with minimal attempts at fixing it, but as explained by Riot in their devblog tech-debt really makes it hard to go back and fix problems like this. Nobody really knows except the people actually paid to solve these kinds of problems in Riot, but say there's around five years of various changes stacked on top of the death recap (every single new champion, ability, updates to minions, etc), then it becomes harder and harder to go back and solve the root problem. 

It's not like League is the only game with this problem. If you've ever played WoW you would find a plethora of bugs that have existed for many years which will likely never get fixed until they decide to make a WoW 2 or something along those lines.
